replies.msg:
äººåœ°å®˜ç¶²æœ‰ä»‹ç´¹é»è§£2016æˆç«‹æ™‚å« Cockroach Studios:

"Whether fiction or documentary, it is our belief that individual vision and work ethic, not multi million dollar budgets– are the building blocks that sustain and propel the medium of film forward. Cockroach Studios is based in Austin, Texas and makes global independent films.

It’s a summer afternoon in Texas, 2016. We are sitting at a local bar throwing ideas around for how to stretch our budget for what would become The Half Light Pilgrim. The conversation quickly shifts to a gentleman at the bar. Next to his fist full of bourbon sits a cowboy hat and a walking stick with a handle like distorted fingers, and on his shirt, a very punk looking cockroach. I introduced myself. One shot of whiskey and cigarette later we are discussing termite art as our new friend Austin leads us to his “office” underneath the bar’s tattoo parlor. A couple of old couches have stacks of original T-shirts. The walls are lined floor to ceiling with several layers of posters of local underground bands and movies. While we admire his collection, Austin digs through the piles of shirts and pulls out one for each of us. The very same punk roach. With them, some pamphlet of pulp art he creates. After another drink at the bar Austin takes his leave and we start discussing the nature of “pulp” or “termite” art. Then we realize while looking at our new attire that we don’t have enough clout to put ourselves in those categories. We’re more like cockroach art.

In most of the world cockroaches are considered a low, dirty form of life. They flow like water, spread like fire and are ridiculously resilient creatures which have been around over 300,000,000 years. They are not particularly pretty things and cause a lot of panic when you find them in your home. When we started making films back in 2015, we felt a certain kinship with the little guys. In an industry focused primarily on the pristine and the beautiful, we are rough around the edges. We are everywhere. We survive. We are more concerned with the edges of society. We use images to shed light on dark places people don’t often look."

quote.msg:
äººåœ°å®˜ç¶²æœ‰ä»‹ç´¹é»è§£2016æˆç«‹æ™‚å« Cockroach Studios:

"Whether fiction or documentary, it is our belief that individual vision and work ethic, not multi million dollar budgets– are the building blocks that sustain and propel the medium of film forward. Cockroach Studios is based in Austin, Texas and makes global independent films.

It’s a summer afternoon in Texas, 2016. We are sitting at a local bar throwing ideas around for how to stretch our budget for what would become The Half Light Pilgrim. The conversation quickly shifts to a gentleman at the bar. Next to his fist full of bourbon sits a cowboy hat and a walking stick with a handle like distorted fingers, and on his shirt, a very punk looking cockroach. I introduced myself. One shot of whiskey and cigarette later we are discussing termite art as our new friend Austin leads us to his “office” underneath the bar’s tattoo parlor. A couple of old couches have stacks of original T-shirts. The walls are lined floor to ceiling with several layers of posters of local underground bands and movies. While we admire his collection, Austin digs through the piles of shirts and pulls out one for each of us. The very same punk roach. With them, some pamphlet of pulp art he creates. After another drink at the bar Austin takes his leave and we start discussing the nature of “pulp” or “termite” art. Then we realize while looking at our new attire that we don’t have enough clout to put ourselves in those categories. We’re more like cockroach art.

In most of the world cockroaches are considered a low, dirty form of life. They flow like water, spread like fire and are ridiculously resilient creatures which have been around over 300,000,000 years. They are not particularly pretty things and cause a lot of panic when you find them in your home. When we started making films back in 2015, we felt a certain kinship with the little guys. In an industry focused primarily on the pristine and the beautiful, we are rough around the edges. We are everywhere. We survive. We are more concerned with the edges of society. We use images to shed light on dark places people don’t often look."

User Reviews

Excellent
17 April 2020 | by roberto-gelleni – See all my reviews
This movie is true independent "grass root" documentary. They worked at jobs from railroad in Switzerland to Starbucks and bartender in Texas, raised every penny, bought their gear, packed up and went to Honk Kong. They owed money to no one and had complete freedom to tell the story as they saw it.

The documentary gives you the feel of being right there with them, although it takes a few minutes to realize how dangerous it was. They run with the protesters, got tear gassed too many times to count, and lived and run the streets.

Top notch documentary for an issue that as it will come up again, can and will have repercussions far from the physical boundaries of Honk Kong.

If they burn, we burn with them.

Cockroach Studios æ—¢ About Us
å””çŸ¥å¹¾æˆçœŸ
ä½¢åœ°å¥½ä¼¼å°±é»æœ‰æ¢æ–°ç‰‡

ABOUT US

Whether fiction or documentary, it is our belief that individual vision and work ethic, not multi million dollar budgets– are the building blocks that sustain and propel the medium of film forward. Cockroach Studios is based in Austin, Texas and makes global independent films. 
It’s a summer afternoon in Texas, 2015. We are sitting at a local bar throwing ideas around for how to stretch our budget for what would become The Half Light Pilgrim. The conversation quickly shifts to a gentleman at the bar. Next to his fist full of bourbon sits a cowboy hat and a walking stick with a handle like distorted fingers, and on his shirt, a very punk looking cockroach. I introduced myself. One shot of whiskey and cigarette later we are discussing termite art as our new friend Austin leads us to his “office” underneath the bar’s tattoo parlor. A couple of old couches have stacks of original T-shirts. The walls are lined floor to ceiling with several layers of posters of local underground bands and movies. While we admire his collection, Austin digs through the piles of shirts and pulls out one for each of us. The very same punk roach. With them, some pamphlet of pulp art he creates. After another drink at the bar Austin takes his leave and we start discussing the nature of “pulp” or “termite” art. Then we realize while looking at our new attire that we don’t have enough clout to put ourselves in those categories. We’re more like cockroach art. 
In most of the world cockroaches are considered a low, dirty form of life. They flow like water, spread like fire and are ridiculously resilient creatures which have been around over 300,000,000 years. They are not particularly pretty things and cause a lot of panic when you find them in your home. When we started making films back in 2015, we felt a certain kinship with the little guys. In an industry focused primarily on the pristine and the beautiful, we are rough around the edges. We are everywhere. We survive. We are more concerned with the edges of society. We use images to shed light on dark places people don’t often look.
